page.title: 04FISHING IN ST. IVES.
page.content: St.Ives was traditionally a fishing village,but the importance of fishing has declined as tourism has increased. Recent changes have seen a{decline}in the number of small part-time hand-lining{mackerel}boats. The larger boats with full-time crews(about{30 men in total) catch crawfish, lobster, monkfish, ray and turbot with{tangle nets. Monofilament{gill-nets}are used for pollock, ling and cod.{Pots are used for crabs and lobsters. Boat designs have changed to{smaller faster craft with{powerful}engines to reach the further fishing grounds more quickly. There two local fishmongers but most is taken by lorry to be sold on the {market}at Newlyn. Some boats take{tourists}on fishing trips and scenic trips to Seal Island.
